g.text: There is little agreement between the various investiga-
tions, and it is possible that different mechanisms exist for
the various garnet phases. It is of critical importance for
such analysis that the crystal chemical model is correct
and that the Li-atom behavior is described properly. An
understanding of the crystal chemical and structural
properties of the two structural modifications of
” is useful for understanding the possible
nature of ion conductivity for Li-oxide garnets in general.
about 1 order of magnitude less at ambient
given in ref 5, whose precise composition was not deter-
mined. An X-ray single-crystal refinement made on flux-
with atomic ratios Li/La/Zr =7.0:3.0:1.9 as determined
by ICP-OES measurements and free of other elements,
Here, the Li cations are ordered
and they occur on three different crystallographic sites,
) are present. The structure is shown
in Figure 7a,b. The crystal structure of tetragonal
which also conducts less well than cubic
”, is similar tothat of tetragonal Li
diffusion pathways are anisotropic in nature being dif-
studied here represents a disordered modification of the
tetragonal phase described in ref 20. In the cubic phase,
several properties could lead to the high Li conductivity.
They are: (i) the single crystallographic tetrahedral C site
) that is statistically occupied with roughly 1/3 Li
atoms; (ii) the short distances between the Li sites; (iii) the
adps for all atoms that are approximately a factor of 2
larger than the corresponding ones for the tetragonal
100 K. This indicates greater static disorder of the Li
, and (iv) The diffusion pathways are iso-
tropic in the Al-containing cubic phase. The
tetragonal modification has anisotropic pathways result-
nances with narrow line widths (Figure 4). This reflects
fast-ion diffusion at room temperature. The Li ions
experience a time-averaged oxygen coordination and
chemical shift interaction similar to Li ions in aqueous
solution. Additional evidence for the fast diffusion is the
tope, which is normally long. Li chemical shift values in
oxides and silicates range from about
garnet suggest that the Li atoms are
spending most of their time at the tetrahedral C (24
site. This interpretation agrees with the diffraction adp
values obtained for Li, because they are smallest for the
the most extensive Li NMR study.
spectra showed two lines at about
intensities of the two lines are dependent on the anneal-
ing temperature of the sample and the resonances were
assigned to Li at tetrahedral and octahedral sites. The
results were interpreted as indicating that the Li atoms
in tetrahedral coordination are immobile, whereas
those at the octahedral site contribute to the dynamics
Li-MAS NMR spectra, made as a
function of temperature, showed a single resonance
that was fit using two superposed lines.
is characterized by lower Li conductivity than
La, and Zr from 100 to 500 K in cubic Al-containing Li
Li2 (5-fold coordinated site) from 100 to 500 K.
ullen, L.; Echelmeyer, T.; Meyer, H.-W.; Wilmer, D.
(39) Thangadurai, V.; Adams, S.; Weppner., W.
